title: 111_hr6214
content: The Act titled "Justice for Rape Victims and Improving Use of DNA Evidence Act of 2010" provides incentive funds under the Byrne Grant Program for states and local governments offering services to victims of sexual assault. Section 505 of the Omnibus Crime Control and Safe Streets Act of 1968 is amended to provide incentive funds for states and local governments that offer services to victims of sexual assault and establish rape kit databases. The amounts allocated to a State or unit of local government will be increased by 10 percent if they meet certain requirements set by the Attorney General. The Omnibus Crime Control and Safe Streets Act of 1968 is amended to require the examination and testing of rape kits for victims of sexual assault by qualified nurses. Results must be provided to the victim within 180 days. States or local governments must also establish and maintain a rape kit database. The Omnibus Crime Control and Safe Streets Act of 1968 now requires states or local governments to maintain a database for rape kits collected from sexual assault victims, with specific requirements for each kit's unique identifying number, date, and location of the assault. The database for rape kits collected from sexual assault victims includes details such as the act of assault, medical examination, testing of the kit, and real-time physical location information. The database for rape kits contains information on testing results and may be accessed publicly without personally identifiable information or shared with law enforcement for identification purposes. The database for rape kits contains information on testing results and may be accessed publicly without personally identifiable information or shared with law enforcement for identification purposes. In judicial proceedings, the information may be admissible, and it can also be shared with healthcare professionals treating victims of sexual assault for medical purposes. Additionally, victims of sexual assault may access information from their rape kit if it pertains to their treatment. The database for rape kits contains searchable information on testing results, accessible by law enforcement for data entry and editing. Funding may be reduced if insufficient. The Attorney General will ratably reduce incentive funds for states and local governments if there are insufficient funds available. Additional appropriations are authorized for incentive funds. Authorized appropriations for incentive funds under this subsection for fiscal years 2011 through 2015. Definitions include 'sexual assault,' 'victim of sexual assault,' 'rape kit,' and 'qualified sexual assault nurse.' The term 'qualified sexual assault nurse examiner' refers to a nurse certified to collect rape kits from sexual assault victims. 'Tested' means a rape kit has undergone forensic analysis, and a 'unique identifying number' is assigned by law enforcement to a rape kit received in connection with a sexual assault. The curr_chunk states that a unique identifying number is used in place of the victim's name in a database for sexual assault cases, except for the victim or law enforcement. The curr_chunk discusses a study and report on DNA backlog. The DNA Analysis Backlog Elimination Act of 2000 is amended to include a study and report to Congress on the backlog of DNA samples collected from crime scenes, victims, and suspects in the United States. The DNA Analysis Backlog Elimination Act of 2000 is amended to include a study on the number of DNA samples collected from crime scenes, victims, suspects, arrestees, and convicted offenders for forensic analysis. The DNA Analysis Backlog Elimination Act of 2000 is amended to include investigations where DNA samples collected from victims of sexual assault are sent to a forensic laboratory for analysis. The average duration of the period between sample collection and submission to the laboratory is to be studied. The DNA Analysis Backlog Elimination Act of 2000 is amended to include investigations where DNA samples from sexual assault victims are sent to a crime laboratory for testing. The Attorney General must submit an annual report to Congress with the study results and statistical analysis of the data. The Attorney General must submit an annual report to Congress with a statistical analysis of DNA data, recommendations to reduce the number of samples subject to conditions, and definitions for the DNA Analysis Backlog Elimination Act of 2000. The definitions in this paragraph clarify terms related to DNA samples, investigations of sexual assault, and the testing of DNA samples through forensic analysis.
